{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3133998,"name":"Bharat Khadka","username":"Bkha1250","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/e47c2d/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-25T23:34:47.273Z","cooked":"

Hi, made a post recently about Pathplanner and how the robot wasn’t going the distance we told it to. With the help of Akash Rastogi from 177 we found out it was a PID problem during auton. We have tuned the PIDs now and the robot goes where it’s supposed to but at the end of the path, the robot always overshoots and keeps going. We’ve tried setting velocity overrides and using the .andThen function to tell the robot to stop but nothing seems to work, we’ve also tried joining multiple paths but that hasn’t led to any solutions because the robot stops short. The path we want is a simple move back and forth to starting position but the robot keeps moving too far. If we stop the path short then the robot will coast to where it started and brakes but then the rest of the path gets screwed up because the robot isn’t where it thinks it is. Is it possible that it could be a gyro drift problem? Any help would be appreciated.

Here’s where the path gets called.

And here is the path folder

The full project can be found at

GitHub

GitHub - Respawn-Robotics/Swiss-Cheese: Prototype Robot Code

Prototype Robot Code. Contribute to Respawn-Robotics/Swiss-Cheese development by creating an account on GitHub.

Here’s a video of the robot
Video (1).zip (1.9 MB)

This is just a simple path and it ends relatively close to where it’s supposed to but for more complex paths the overshoot is larger

Respawn-Robotics/Swiss-Cheese: Prototype Robot Code","clicks":39},{"url":"https://github.com/Respawn-Robotics/Swiss-Cheese/blob/master/src/main/java/frc/robot/autos/exampleAuto.java","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Swiss-Cheese/exampleAuto.java at master · Respawn-Robotics/Swiss-Cheese · GitHub","clicks":23},{"url":"https://github.com/Respawn-Robotics/Swiss-Cheese/blob/master/src/main/deploy/pathplanner/BackAndForth.path","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Swiss-Cheese/BackAndForth.path at master · Respawn-Robotics/Swiss-Cheese · GitHub","clicks":12},{"url":"/uploads/short-url/pRTGxcwEHk3iOCZo24qNDtl7kse.zip","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56681,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/pathplanner-not-1-1-with-robot-path/424687/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3134010,"name":"Fletch","username":"Fletch1373","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-25T23:50:53.263Z","cooked":"

If we’re talking linear motion (just forward and back, no rotation), then its definitely not a gyro drift problem.

I havent looked at the code or video yet (on my phone), but what drivetrain are you using? Motor controllers in brake or coast mode? Have you tried the alternative?

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2023-01-25T23:50:53.263Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":401,"readers_count":400,"score":90.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":424687,"topic_slug":"pathplanner-not-1-1-with-robot-path","display_username":"Fletch","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9105,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades"},"post_url":"/t/pathplanner-not-1-1-with-robot-path/424687/2","custom_user_title":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3134057,"name":"Bharat Khadka","username":"Bkha1250","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/e47c2d/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-26T00:47:24.783Z","cooked":"

We are using MK4 Swervedrives with Falcon 500s from Swerve Drive Specialties. The drive motors are set to brake and the turn motors are on coast. We have not tried the alternative because that was the default mode in the BaseFalconSwerve code but I’ll let you know what happens.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2023-01-26T00:47:24.783Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":382,"readers_count":381,"score":86.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":424687,"topic_slug":"pathplanner-not-1-1-with-robot-path","display_username":"Bharat Khadka","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":9105,"username":"Fletch1373","name":"Fletch","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56681,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/pathplanner-not-1-1-with-robot-path/424687/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3134058,"name":"Bharat Khadka","username":"Bkha1250","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/e47c2d/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-26T00:54:32.270Z","cooked":"

We tried setting the angle motor to brake and the drive to coast and nothing changed. Initially we thought the problem was that the motors weren’t being set to 0 velocity from the path planner code but when we checked the json file we saw that the velocity is set to 0. We were also thinking that the path ended but the wheels coast past the intended location but we’re not sure how to account for that.

This might be the problem, notice how the end point’s white dot and the start point’s white dot are not the same distance, the velocity might be different resulting in the overshoot.

Try moving the end point’s dot closer.

Thank you, we will try this idea tomorrow, with any luck it’ll work. For any teams that also use path planner, did you guys also struggle to get it fully working, or was it plug-and-play?

We had the same problem where it cut short near the end. I did notice the dot distance offset and fixed it, we haven’t tried it but hopefully it works!

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2023-01-26T12:30:22.264Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":249,"readers_count":248,"score":79.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":424687,"topic_slug":"pathplanner-not-1-1-with-robot-path","display_username":"Jainish Patel","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":56681,"username":"Bkha1250","name":"Bharat Khadka","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/e47c2d/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54172,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4065 NOP | Programming Lead"},"post_url":"/t/pathplanner-not-1-1-with-robot-path/424687/12","custom_user_title":"4065 NOP | Programming Lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3134348,"name":"Michael Jansen","username":"mjansen4857","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mjansen4857/{size}/201972_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-26T17:09:26.138Z","cooked":"

It looks like your issue is probably with your PID constants. You have them negative, which will just increase error instead of minimizing it. Even if they were positive, they are pretty low so it won’t do much to actually correct for error. I’d try setting the P value of the X and Y controllers to ~5, which is a value I’ve seen work well. For the rotation P, try ~0.5.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2023-01-26T17:09:26.138Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":233,"readers_count":232,"score":146.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":424687,"topic_slug":"pathplanner-not-1-1-with-robot-path","display_username":"Michael Jansen","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":33850,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3015 Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/pathplanner-not-1-1-with-robot-path/424687/13","custom_user_title":"3015 Programming Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3134731,"name":"Bharat Khadka","username":"Bkha1250","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/e47c2d/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-27T04:00:04.626Z","cooked":"

Thank you for your response. We’ve tried setting the values similar to other teams but every positive value above 1 makes the robot overshoot by a lot. Having a high negative value made the robot back up in the middle of the path but -.125 was the only value that would get the robot to go to the target position. We’ll try using the values you suggested and I’m sure that we’re probably missing something but do you have any tips for tuning PIDs for auton?

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2023-01-27T04:00:04.626Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":13,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":214,"readers_count":213,"score":82.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":424687,"topic_slug":"pathplanner-not-1-1-with-robot-path","display_username":"Bharat Khadka","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":33850,"username":"mjansen4857","name":"Michael Jansen","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mjansen4857/{size}/201972_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56681,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/pathplanner-not-1-1-with-robot-path/424687/14","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3134740,"name":"Michael Jansen","username":"mjansen4857","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mjansen4857/{size}/201972_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-27T04:19:06.174Z","cooked":"

You definitely don’t want a negative value. You’re essentially just getting to the target position on accident. How these PID values work for the path following command is that the P value is multiplied by the position error. If you are, for example, 0.2 meters behind where you should be, it will add an extra 0.2 * P meters per second to the current state of the path. So, with a negative P value, you would be subtracting velocity when you are falling behind, and adding velocity when you are getting ahead of the path.

You might want to try running the path following with 0 for all of your P values. This should be able to get pretty close on its own. If its anything more than a few inches off with a pretty simple path (like a straight line) then you might want to take a look at the wheel velocity PID or conversion from encoder units to m/s on your modules. If your modules aren’t managing to go the velocity that you are telling them to go, this will cause a lot of inaccuracy.

If your modules are fine, then you can try graphing the error in glass or advantage scope or something. By default, the path following commands will publish X, Y, and rotation error to smart dashboard for this purpose (new PPLib update added custom logging callbacks if you want to handle it some other way). You could also try to use a Field2d widget or PPLib server to visualize the path following by showing the current robot pose and the target robot pose on the field. If the actual pose is consistently off from the target, add more P. If the actual pose keeps oscillating around the target or the robot is making some awful noises, use less P. You can go a lot crazier with PID tuning but just tuning the P value while graphing the error can get you to a really good spot.

Edit: Another thing you may want to check is that you’re not trying to push the robot too hard in the path. In other words, make sure the max velocity and acceleration of the path are actually attainable by the robot. If your robot can only go 3.5 m/s but the path expects it to go 4 m/s, there is no chance you will be able to stay on target.

Sorry for the late response, thank you for the information. We discovered that the problem was with the drive PID constant set for all drive motors earlier in the code. After some experimenting, we discovered that having a value of 0 for kX and kY was good but struggled to see a difference in changing the kTheta constant above 1. The robot moves accurately to positions now but we’re still seeing shifts in the X and Y of the path when we include holonomic rotations. We’re not really sure what other steps we can take to fix these issues so we considered just adjusting the path to be longer to make up for the shortage in drive distance. I can’t currently upload any videos but I can elaborate more tomorrow evening. That issue aside, we used Sysid to try and characterize our robot and got our kV, kS, and kA values but we don’t currently know how to calculate our maximum velocity and acceleration. We’ve been using default values provided by 364’s BaseFalconSwerve and Pathplanner but we’d like to find our own values. Do you have any tips on how to find our robot’s max velocity and acceleration? Is there a tool or would we have to code the calculations?

Logging the velocity to a wpilib datalog and then driving full speed full acceleration a few times can help you experimentally get the data. You could use advantagescope to graph it and see statistics, or you could convert it to csv and open in excel for more stuff.
